ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned an introduction to Calculus 1 and its application to real-life scenarios, which was a nice refresher to the knowledge of calculus that I learned with IB Math applications and interpretations.
I learned how to problem solve
I improved my abilities in algebra as well as skills in differential calculus like taking derivatives, using limits, finding antiderivatives and integrals, and evaluating differential equations.
I learnt about single variable calculus and its real life uses as with displacement and velocity.
Basic intro calc skills, derivatives, integrals, limits, etc
An introduction to calculus at a speed that is easy to follow and keep up with
Strengthened skills in analysis and my foundation in math.

By taking this course, I learned a lot of calculus and new mathematical concepts. I also learned why some of these concepts work from doing proofs in class, and why they matter in real life. I gained insight into the environment of a college class, and learned independence and self-advocacy skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Not much teaching happened in class and the problem sets were unnecessarily difficult.

I liked the emphasis on mastery for the derivative rules. I feel like it's a good way to prioritize learning rather than test-taking. I'm not sure of any recommendations I would make for how to improve the course.

The problem sets were very helpful in terms of practicing the content. The exams and midterms were also very well set up to ensure that students understood the information well and were a very good way of testing the students. I think the derivative computer was also useful.
I thought the course was about as good as it could be for the content

Strengths: the midterms and psets are proportional to what is being taught. Ximera was an especially useful resource. 

Weaknesses: I didnt find the classes themselves extremely productive or engaging. I felt like I didnt leave class fully having mastered a topic but instead found Ximera more useful.

Strengths: the professors, the resources, the feedback, the course format

Weaknesses: Ability to improve in Psets

One of the strengths was teacher, because they were very patient and willing to help, in class and at office hours. Some other things I liked were the guided notes, review sessions before exams, and being allowed to use a one-pager when taking exams.
I think one of the weaknesses of the course is that what we were taught in class wasn't always enough, and often much simpler than the homework, so at times, the homework was very confusing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but only if you have to take a Calculus class for a major/degree requirement
Yes, it was a good building of my foundation of calculus.

It's a math class, so I would recommend it if you're looking to take a math class (for whatever reason) and this is the right level for you. I would like to say that I would recommend taking it with Professor Barnes, since I enjoyed having him as a professor, but he's leaving after this semester and I don't have experience learning from any of the other professors, so I can't provide any recommendations regarding them.
Yes. It is very well run and very well-structured.
If they need to take it
Yes, if it is required
Yes!! Especially if Eric and James are teaching/guiding the course. They were both amazing and were highlights of my semester!!

I would recommend this course to another student because the teachers were all very kind, patient, and willing to help. There were lots of opportunities students could take to get help, such as office hours, peer tutoring, and review sessions. Every class, we got guided notes, and every week, we got a new problem set. We always knew what was coming up because the teachers communicated through announcements on Canvas, so we were always given an adequate chance to prepare.
